repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26744

Windows did not support underline syles other than the regular one. no undercurl or double line . but with the latest merge these has been implemented and planned for https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/pull/16097.

in the latest Preview you can see this in action using powershell >= 6 (Cmd as far as i know does not support escape chars. correct me if i am wrong )

using both
```
Write-Host "`e[4:3mtest`e[0m"
Write-Host "`e[4:3;58:2::000:255:000mtest`e[0m"
```
will print both colored non colored undercurl

![292871937-1c559811-e124-4354-8d67-cacc0f3f78a2](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/27051374/71d3c54f-ed0d-4ad5-91a3-9c12e61bd2b9)

Adding the paramaters in the terminfo for vtpcon will give full support for underline style rendering in native windows. I assume this will also give support to other terminals other than windows terminal like wezterm and alacritty as  these are relient on windows terminal conptty implementation which should update as soon as the preview branch merge into the stable one. 

To test this out download the latest Windows terminal Preview from either github or Windows store.

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/27051374/c84e089e-2d0b-480a-a012-1cb6de8b0871)

Thanks to @tusharsnx and @kmoschcau for the inspiration.

After looking at it. The file is generated with ncurses and I used the stable. It seem like this has been updated recently. generating a new one with the committed one from master

comment_regular_data.body: Thank you BTW for your time and for reviewing @zeertzjq . And sorry for the mess created earlier on.

@ajmandourah Thanks for doing this! 


An important point we need to discuss is

Have you tested this on terminals that do not support colored underlines (`SGR 58/59`) and extended underline styles (`SGR 4:X`)?

The problem with these sub parameter (colon `:` syntax) based control sequences are, if we send the sequence to unsupported terminals, they'll not render anything.

Neovim, when not using `SGR 4:X` and `SGR 58`, sends standard `SGR 4` for all underlines (except double underline `SGR 21`), and don't even send `SGR 58` at all. This is important to keep unsupported terminals working as usual.

Unfortunately, feature detection in terminals isn't the best. You could've used [DECRQSS](https://vt100.net/docs/vt510-rm/DECRQSS.html) and [DECRPSS](https://vt100.net/docs/vt510-rm/DECRPSS.html), but that'll let you know the capability of backing conhost and not of the terminal user is interacting with ðŸ¥²

So, I think we should add a config like `compatibility.legacy_underline_styles` to help user revert to older behavior (i.e only `SGR 4` and no `SGR 4:X`). Sending `SGR 58` to unsupported terminals won't hurt I guess. I'm also not an nvim expert, so maybe there's already a way to turn off extended styles. In that case, mentioning that in the docs should be enough ðŸ™‚

@tusharsnx 

You are right.  here is a comparision

left: with current modification. current windows terminal (underline styles + colors not supported yet)
middle: with old terminfo. current windows terminal (underline styles + colors not supported yet)
right: with modifications. windows terminal preview (with support for underline styles and colors)

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/27051374/8f8e815e-aa3d-4c0b-b3d0-02ab2266876e)

from my understanding other terminals like Putty for example have their own terminfo defined in the terminfo_defs.h I made sure not to touch those .

So, what we are looking for is to get _left_ to work as _middle_ with the current changeset. Can we (as a user) edit `Smulx` (or something similar) to get the terminal on the _left_ to show the missing underlines?

> So, what we are looking for is to get _left_ to work as _middle_ with the current changeset. Can we (as a user) edit `Smulx` (or something similar) to get the terminal on the _left_ to show the missing underlines?

You are probably right but the question is if we really need to do so . I have just tried alacritty and wezterm, 2 of the most popular terminals for windows and they both shows the correct underline (middle). As Windows terminal will eventually will support underlines when they merge it into the stable which i recon to be soon, I doubt we will need to implement a feature which may not be used. 

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/27051374/5d1d75b4-20a4-4ac3-b6ad-5df91de96de8)

again . other terminals like putty and conemu have their own terminfo defined in the header file so these probably wont be affected. did not try though .

> You are probably right but the question is if we really need to do so.

I think we need it because it's considered as a breaking change for unsupported terminals. This is probably why Neovim blocks this feature unless a terminal explicitly says (through terminfo, or similar methods) that it supports these extended control sequences.

> I doubt we will need to implement a feature which may not be used

This will used as a last resort for unsupported terminals. Though, we might not need it right now ðŸ¤”

*I'm okay with what core maintainers think is right for Neovim to do here.*

Fair. Do you happen to know what terminals other than the mentioned above ? i will try to test them out and see how they react . To be honest i don't know if its possible to modify only the terminfo files only without touching the source code for the implementation to get the desire outcome. i don't feel very comfortable but i will try my best.

Turns out the latest windows terminal stable Windows Terminal Version: 1.19.10302.0 is already supporting colorized underlines. (my laptop was outdated and refused to update from the app store. a manual installation from github fixed it)

title: feat(terminfo): support colorized underline styles in vtpcon
